parse: Interrogative / Indefinite Pronoun - Nominative Masculine Plural
str2: Any one, some one, a certain one or thing. An enclitic indefinite pronoun; some or any person or object.
From out, out from among, from, suggesting from the interior outwards. A primary preposition denoting origin, from, out.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive Masculine 3rd Person Plural
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Passive - 3rd Person Plural
str2: A primary verb; to convince; by analogy, to pacify or conciliate; reflexively or passively, to assent, to rely.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Passive - 3rd Person Plural
str2: From pros and kleroo; to give a common lot to, i.e. to associate with.
Paul, Paulus. Of Latin origin; Paulus, the name of a Roman and of an apostle.
And, even, also, namely.
Silas, a pet-form of the name Silvanus; a Roman citizen and a helper of Paul. Contraction for Silouanos; Silas, a Christian.
And, both. A primary particle of connection or addition; both or also.
Much, many; often.
A multitude, crowd, great number, assemblage. From pletho; a fulness, i.e. A large number, throng, populace.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Middle or Passive - Genitive Masculine Plural
str2: To reverence, worship, adore. Middle voice of an apparently primary verb; to revere, i.e. Adore.
From Hellas; a Hellen or inhabitant of Hellas; by extension a Greek-speaking person, especially a non-Jew.
And, both. A primary particle of connection or addition; both or also.
No, not. Also ouk, and ouch a primary word; the absolute negative adverb; no or not.
Puny; especially neuter somewhat.
First, before, principal, most important. Contracted superlative of pro; foremost.
A woman, wife, my lady. Probably from the base of ginomai; a woman; specially, a wife.
